displayed_text: Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then I’ll print out these consent forms for you that you can take and sort of that he can look at as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we can sort of decide which one makes more sense for you, or none of them may make any sense, and that really because your scans or worse, you’re having more symptoms. You know the textbook answer right now is go to chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm. Patient: And how soon would that start? Doctor: Uh that would be more—again, based on scans and scheduling. Patient: Okay and then who’s going to order the scans? Doctor: So that’s what I’ve got to talk to Dr. G__ about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you’ve already got the test scans, what’s the plan? Because we need to get pictures to sort of say yes, you’ve progressed. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Patient: Okay, good. Family Member: So how will you know? Doctor: Well I think - Patient: Symptoms. Doctor: - both PSA and scans. We’ll probably plan on doing scans again in three months. Okay. Family Member: His last PSA do you have the results of that? Because we didn’t get uh… Where did you have that done? Doctor: I only have CBC’s from outside, so I think - Patient: I had I had a PSA done. Doctor: - today’s PSA is going to be your one in a long time. Family Member: Okay well he had one… Doctor: Because when they did it in F____ all they did is only blood counts right? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah, B___ City.

Patient: That’s what I’m sayin’. So, Doctor: Yes. So, maybe it’s something Patient: That’s all, so what it does, is that a fact, can it happen like that? Can they do that? Like, is it, like I had diarrhea before, Doctor: Yeah. Are you taking any laxative or a stool softener or anything? Patient: Yeah. That’s what I’m sayin’ to you that stool softener don’t Doctor: Stop that then, because that’s, uh, worsening your diarrhea. Patient: Is it? Doctor: I may need to give you medicine to help control it. Like Imodium and things like that. Patient: Yeah, well then, okay. ‘Cuz, yeah, I’m taking the stool softener a day thinking that, that, that, you know? And then it be like watery. Doctor: Mmm, hmm. Patient: Yeah. It be like, it be like water. Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I think I’m going to give you medication. That way, when you’re out and about and all that, you can take that, and that won’t make you go so fast.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s - Doctor: Then you’re taking Vitamin D, a thousand units a day. Patient: Doing that. Doctor: And uh so (_-pine name of drug) Patient: Yes. Doctor: And it looks like it’s working and then Oxybutynin for bladder spasms. Patient: Okay, I had - I had some urinary infection, and they gave me seven days’ uh - Family Member: I think Patient: And I finished that last night. Doctor: And so did they give you something also for spasms? Patient: No. Doctor: So Oxybutynin. Family Member: Uh well yes, they did but he decided not to take that.

Patient: So did you like Budapest? Doctor: Yes, it was interesting. I mean I had limited time, but it was… Patient: Yeah we did too. Doctor: I don’t think I would have ever thought of Budapest to visit if it weren’t for this meeting where I to be there. Patient: Yeah yeah right. Well we had been there. Doctor: It’s an incredible city. Oh my gosh! Like I never knew about, never thought about. Patient: And we never had enough time either. Doctor: Really? Even you went on your cruise right? Family Member: We were supposed to be there two days but then we had some problems with the boat so we had – they limited it to one day. They had to cut out some things. Doctor: And you thought that wasn’t… Patient: No. Family Member: No.

Family Member: They gave me this application to fill out. Doctor: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that. Family Member: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or… Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given - Doctor: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree. Family Member: But what I appreciate right now is that you’re listening to us. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because even outside of his care, you want to be treated humanely. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member: Or we’ll stay at home and he needs this place. Doctor: I would agree. Who doesn’t need a roof over the heads first of all?

Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And it cannot substitute as a weight loss plan. Doctor: Let me just say it for the record. Patient: Well, yeah. We’re working on that part of it. Family Member: Yes. We are.

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: APS. Patient: She came here actually for one of the world experts on APS. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Which is a blood disorder. Clotting. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: I thought I would mention it ‘cuz I think for her – Doctor: I don’t know enough about that. I’d have to read up about that, but I don’t think it relates. Family Member: For her, it was a really easy fix. Doctor: That’s not a gene on this panel that they did for you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They do more common cancer genes. Family Member: Oh, I see.

Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic. Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the… Doctor: You had K____ Patient: K__ left. Doctor: but K____ left me so J____ is now working with me but actually J____ and I have worked together in the fifteen years I’ve been here. So, she was my original nurse that did a whole bunch of stuff but she’s always stayed on this team so she is also a very you know excellent prostate expert so she is going to help with trying to figure out if your insurance will say yes because it’s all great that you and I agree but if your insurance says, what are you kidding me, then we have to take that option off the table and just move on. Sound okay? Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: It’s kind of a lot today isn’t it? Patient: I want the best of what the best is for.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, that is why. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Aximun scan may help and may also confuse thing. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But I'll hear from you anything that says we got to rush to therapy make a decision right now that I just need to figure out. We are adding Aximun scans to our scanning facility but we don't do them now. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And with time, like more months, like up to September. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: In September if that that – if nothing happens, then we can go to another ah step Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: in treating the sexual function. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Injections into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh but that’s I don’t know if I gave you a book about that or not. Patient: Uh no, no you just you know you discussed the options. Doctor: Well I’ll get you some literature about that, but injections would be the next step.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven. Three plus four is seven or equals seven. Those two um numbers are different depending Gleason if

Family Member: No. He did not. Hum. Doctor: Okay. So did you explain anything to her? Patient: No. She tell me- Family Member: No. But, yes, this is why, right. Yes. This is why I’m here. Doctor: Ah. Okay. Family Member: Because I can’t get a good understanding. Doctor: Okay. Okay. We know the baseline stuff – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - that he has. Family Member: Exactly. Doctor: That’s basically still there. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But because the PSA was doing a little bit of this creep up-
